perturbation.original_text: 16.01 Investor at any time may provide written notice to Company of a material breach of this IP Agreement. If Company fails to cure the identified breach within thirty (30) days after the date of the notice, Investor may terminate this IP Agreement by written notice to Company.
perturbation.changed_text: 16.01 Investor at any time may provide written notice to Company of a material breach of this IP Agreement. If Company fails to cure the identified breach within ten (10) days after the date of the notice, Investor may terminate this IP Agreement by written notice to Company.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the cure period for a material breach from 30 days to 10 days could be considered unreasonably short, especially given the complexity of IP agreements and the potential need for extensive investigation and remediation. This could violate the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing present in most US jurisdictions, as it doesn't allow a reasonable timeframe for the breaching party to address the issue.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing under New York law (since section 13.00 states that this IP Agreement will be construed in accordance with the substantive laws of the state of New York).

perturbation.original_text: 4.00 Company will have the sole right to file, prosecute, and maintain all Patents covering the inventions that are the property of Company and will have the right to determine whether or not, and where, to file a patent application, to abandon the prosecution of any patent or patent application, or to discontinue the maintenance of any patent or patent application. Notwithstanding the foregoing, if Company elects to abandon any patent application, to not pay maintenance fees or annuities to keep a patent in force, or to otherwise take or fail to take any action that will result in a loss of patent rights, Company shall give Investor at least sixty (60) days prior written notice and an opportunity to take over the prosecution of the patent application that would be abandoned and/or pay the fees necessary to keep the patent in force and/or take any other action necessary to avoid the loss of patent rights.
perturbation.changed_text: 4.00 Company will have the sole right to file, prosecute, and maintain all Patents covering the inventions that are the property of Company and will have the right to determine whether or not, and where, to file a patent application, to abandon the prosecution of any patent or patent application, or to discontinue the maintenance of any patent or patent application. Notwithstanding the foregoing, if Company elects to abandon any patent application, to not pay maintenance fees or annuities to keep a patent in force, or to otherwise take or fail to take any action that will result in a loss of patent rights, Company shall give Investor at least ten (10) days prior written notice and an opportunity to take over the prosecution of the patent application that would be abandoned and/or pay the fees necessary to keep the patent in force and/or take any other action necessary to avoid the loss of patent rights.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the notice period for patent abandonment from 60 days to 10 days is insufficient to allow the investor to properly assess the value of the patent and take necessary steps to continue prosecution or maintenance. This can be considered a breach of good faith, especially if the patents are critical to the investor's business, as the investor needs time to assess its options, secure funding, and engage patent counsel.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing under New York law (since section 13.00 states that this IP Agreement will be construed in accordance with the substantive laws of the state of New York).

perturbation.original_text: 18.03 Litigation or Arbitration as a Final Resort. If the Parties cannot resolve any Dispute for any reason, including, but not limited to, the failure of the Parties to agree to enter into mediation or agree to any settlement proposed by the mediator, within sixty (60) days after the Escalation to Mediation Date, either the Company or the Holder may file suit in a court of competent jurisdiction in accordance with Article 18.04.
perturbation.changed_text: 18.03 Litigation or Arbitration as a Final Resort. If the Parties cannot resolve any Dispute for any reason, including, but not limited to, the failure of the Parties to agree to enter into mediation or agree to any settlement proposed by the mediator, within ten (10) days after the Escalation to Mediation Date, either the Company or the Holder may file suit in a court of competent jurisdiction in accordance with Article 18.04.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the time frame to file a suit after mediation from 60 days to 10 days is insufficient time to review the situation, prepare legal options, and decide on the best course of action. This can be considered a breach of good faith, which needs time to make decisions, hire a legal advisor to work on the cases. Therefore, this time frame would be a breach.
